title: Apply - Immigrate to Brazil - Comprehensive Guide to Brazil Immigra...
description: Step-by-step guidance to apply for your Brazilian visa
heading: Start Your Immigration Journey

sections.title: Introduction
paragraphs: Step-by-step guidance to apply for your Brazilian visa

sections.title: Application Steps
paragraphs: Step 7: Receive Visa & Travel to Brazil
Your first decision determines everything else about your application. Review all visa options:
Order certified copies of all documents. Apostille documents (Hague Apostille) in your country of origin.

Critical:
All documents must be officially translated to Portuguese
Allow 2-4 weeks for full translation and certification
Find the consulate jurisdiction for your home address
You must apply at the consulate covering your residence, not your citizenship
Interview typically lasts 10-30 minutes. Consulate staff assess your application for completeness and eligibility.
Most visas expire 90 days after issue. You must travel within this window.

Work Visa:
Have a job offer from a Brazilian employer

Investor Visa:
Plan to invest and start a business

Family Visa:
Have Brazilian family members

Rentista/Aposentado:
Have passive income or retirement funds

Student Visa:
Enrolled in a Brazilian institution

Remote Work:
Work for international company remotely
Criminal background check from your country

Work:
Job offer letter, employer sponsorship document

Investor:
Business plan, investment proof, bank statements

Financial:
Income statements, bank account records
Find a certified translator (juramentado) in your city
Receive official translated documents with translator's stamp
Apostille service: $5-20 per document (varies by country)
Visit Ministry of Foreign Affairs: www.gov.br/mre
Note address, phone number, and website
North America: New York, Los Angeles, Miami, Toronto, Mexico City
Europe: London, Paris, Berlin, Madrid, Rome, Lisbon
Asia: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Delhi
Others: Australia, Middle East, Africa, South America
Contact consulate (phone, email, or online system)
Schedule at least 2-4 weeks in advance
Bring all original documents and translated copies
Be prepared to answer questions about your application
Follow up if you don't hear after stated timeline
Don't book flights until visa is approved
Pick up your passport with visa stamp
Book flight for within visa validity period
Bring: Passport with visa, return ticket, hotel reservations
Have contact information for your employer/sponsor
You now have temporary residence in Brazil
Provide proof of address (rental contract, hotel receipt)
Receive RNE (Carteira de Residente - residency card)

sections.title: Application Timeline Summary
paragraphs: Gather and prepare all documents, get translations and apostille
Schedule consulate appointment and submit application
Wait for visa approval (varies by visa type)
Receive visa, book flights, prepare for move
Travel to Brazil and begin your new life

sections.title: Useful Resources for Application
paragraphs: Do I need authorization from Brazil first?

sections.title: Get Expert Help
paragraphs: Consider hiring an immigration lawyer if your case is complex. They can:
Many companies specialize in helping people move to Brazil. Services include:

sections.title: Still Have Questions?
paragraphs: Review our complete guides for more information about each step.
